metadata.title: Immobilized copper iodide on a porous organic polymer bearing P,N-ligation sites: A highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for C<ce:glyph name=sbnd></ce:glyph>O bond formation reaction

Immobilized copper iodide on a porous organic polymer bearing P,N-ligation sites: A highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for CO bond formation reaction Nasser Iranpoor a ⁎ Farhad Panahi a b ⁎ Fatemeh Roozbin a Sajjad Rahimi a Mohsen Golbon Haghighi c a Department of Chemistry, College of Sciences, Shiraz University, Shiraz 71454, Iran Department of Chemistry College of Sciences Shiraz University Shiraz 71454 Iran b Department of Polymer Engineering and Color Technology, Amirkabir University of Technology, Tehran, Iran Department of Polymer Engineering and Color Technology Amirkabir University of Technology Tehran Iran c Department of Chemistry, Shahid Beheshti University, Evin, Tehran 19839-69411, Iran Department of Chemistry Shahid Beheshti University Evin Tehran 19839-69411 Iran ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Department of Chemistry, College of Sciences, Shiraz University, Shiraz 71454, Iran. Graphical abstract Immobilized copper iodide on a triazine-phosphite porous organic polymer (CuI-TP-POP) was introduced as a novel heterogeneous catalyst, to be used in CO band formation reaction. The CuI-TP-POP catalyst was synthesized by complexation of CuI with a triazine-phosphite porous organic polymer (TP-POP), incorporating P,N-ligation sites. The TP-POP substrate is a porous material in sheet morphology with cavities in the range of nanometer scale incorporating P and N atoms. These nano-cavities create appropriate ligation sites on the surface of TP-POP with chelation character to coordinate with CuI, leading to the formation of a heterogeneous copper (I) catalyst. The CuI-TP-POP was found to be an efficient heterogeneous catalyst in CO bond formation reaction between phenolic compounds and aryl halides toward synthesis of diaryl ethers in high isolated yields. This catalyst system was reusable at least for five times without significant decreasing in its catalytic activity. Keywords Porous organic polymers (POP) Triazine-phosphite (TP) polymer P,N-Ligand Heterogeneous catalyst CO bond formation reaction 1 Introduction The use of transition metal-catalysts for the construction of CO bond has received considerable attention, due to their widespread applications in medicinal chemistry and organic synthesis [1–6]. The use of copper catalysts in CO bond formation reactions is attractive from both industrial and academic perspective; mostly due to its availability and cheapness [7–11]. The Cu-catalyzed CO bond formation reaction provides an essential synthetic route in synthesis of many natural products and biologically active molecules [12–20]. Cu-catalyzed O-arylation reaction has extensively developed and there are different types of synthetic methodologies which are useful for coupling of diverse hydroxy-functionalized compounds with organohalides and pseudohalides to construct desired ether compounds [21–39]. Notice that the Cu-catalyzed O-arylation reactions often need suitable ligands to improve the reaction outcome and most of the researches in this field focused on the introduction of new and efficient ligands. Due to their high activity and selectivity, P,N-ligands are among the most widely used ligands in transition-metal-catalyzed coupling reactions [40–42]. These heteroatomic bidentate ligands are containing heteroatoms of P and N which can chelate metals to produce a highly active and stable complexes. These interesting characteristics promted chemists to focous their attention on design of new P,N-ligands [43–55]. There are two key factors which have been considered in the synthesis of new P,N-ligands: (1) stronger chelating ability (for more reactivity and selectivity) and (2) the possibility of recycling. The importance of reusability factor in P,N-ligands is resulted from this fact that these ligands are often expensive and synthetic routes for their preparation are usually complicated. Immobilized of P,N-ligands on a solid support such as polymers and metal oxides for their heterogenization was also reported [56,57]. One of the interesting classes of materials which have been considered in the recent years is porous organic polymers (POPs) [58–61]. This class of polymers has porous structure incorporating organic functionalities which can be used in synthetic diversification and also direct utilizations. Subunits of POPs react together with covalent bonds and generate micro-porous networks. Due to the porosity of this class of polymers they have high surface area. Depended to the used monomers for their synthesis, it is possible to have a wide range of chemical functionalities in their structures. Overall, POPs can be divided into three major classes: (1) POPs that incorporate rigid well-defined homogeneous catalysts as building blocks, (2) POPs that can be modified post-synthesis, and (3) POPs that encapsulate metal particles [62]. The uses of metal-functionalized POPs that possesses important properties such as catalytic activities, molecular separation, electronics and gas sorption have been reported [63–69]. The importance of POPs originated from this fact that they merge the properties of both metal and organic fragments which are included in the porous structure of the material. Very recently, a new type of POPs incorporating P,N-ligation sites was introduced by our reaserch group. This new POP was synthesized using a simple procedure and also cheap and abundant starting materials [70]. In this way, cyanuric acid (1,3,5-triazine-2,4,6-triol) was reacted with trichlorophosphine (PCl3) in the presence of triethylamine as base and triazine-phosphite polymeric material (TP-POP) was obtained in high isolated yield. The TP-POP compound is a reusable substrate containing P and N atoms having chelation sites for coordination with metals. Herein, the complexation of TP-POP with CuI was resulted in the production of a heterogeneous copper catalyst system (CuI-TP-POP) for application in Cu-catalyzed organic reactions. The catalytic applicability of CuI-TP-POP was investigated in CO bond formation reaction between aryl halides and phenols for synthesis of aryl ethers under heterogeneous condition. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterization The TP-POP polymeric compound material was synthesized according to our previous report [70]. The synthetic route for the synthesis of CuI-TP-POP as a new heterogeneous catalyst is shown in Scheme 1 . The TP-POP substrate (1.0g) was reacted with CuI (0.190g, 1.0mmol) at 50°C in DMF (10mL) for 12h in order to prepare CuI-TP-POP catalyst. The complexation of CuI and TP-POP was investigated using UV–vis spectroscopy at temperatures of 50°C in DMF solvent. The uv- vis absorption spectraum of CuI-TP-POP complexe show some peakes (Fig. 1 a). A main peak was shown around 250–300nm with some shoulders because of charge transfer and d–d transitions of copper complex. The UV–vis spectrum indicating the complexation of TP-POP with CuI and its conversion to the CuI-TP-POP catalyst. Sharp peak at 200nm is due to the quartz cell absorption that used to obtain the UV–vis absorption. The yellow color of polymer after complexation with CuI converted to gray. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectra of the CuI-TP-POP catalyst (Fig. 1b) show the elements of C, N, O, P, Cu and I. Based on the amount of 5.43% for Cu, it is possible to calculate the amount of the immobilized CuI in the structure of TP-POP which is equal to 0.85mmol/gram of the material. Also, in order to confirm the Cu content, the supported catalyst was treated with concentrated HCl and HNO3 to digest the Cu species and then was analyzed by ICP analysis. The Cu content was determined to be 51.3ppm (51.3mgL−1), which is equal to 5.13% w/w. Fig. 2 shows the elemental mapping analysis of CuI-TP-POP catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2, the orange and green dots with bright color assigned to the Cu and I element, respectively, are uniformly distributed on the surface of TP-POP substrate. For comparison, the N (yellow), O (blue) and P (red) elemental mapping have also been represented, which displays the presence of these elements uniformly on the surface of material. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images of CuI-TP-POP catalyst is shown in Fig. 3 . As shown, the TP-POP strings form skins in the sheet morphology with cavities in the range of nanometers (Fig. 3a). This nano-porous material is containing P,N-ligation sites which can corrdinate with CuI to afford a heterogeneous metal complex suitable for catalysis purposes. The nanoporous nature of the material after complexation with CuI is remained unchanged. Although, Fig. 3f shows some particles which may be due to the agglomeration of CuI nanoparticles. The FT-IR spectra of both TP-POP and CuI-TP-POP are shown in Fig. 4 . The comparison between the FT-IR spectra of TP-POP and CuI-TP-POP shows that most of the absorption bands of the polymeric support are remained unchanged in the CuI-TP-POP catalyst with insignificant shifts [71]. The PO bond in the polymeric ligand is observed at 851cm−1 while after complexation with CuI shifted to 857cm−1 demonstrating the complexation of CuI with ligation sites of the ligand [72]. The CuN bond in the FT-IR spectrum should appear around 400–500cm−1 which this area is covered by other substrate peaks [73]. The XRD patterns of both TP-POP and CuI-TP-POP are shown in Fig. 5 . The TP-POP shows characteristic peaks at 2θ=17.1, 19.6, 22.3, 26.2, 29.5, 34.4, 36.4, 37.9, 40.2 and 41.7. After complexation of TP-POP with CuI these peaks appeared with negligible shift. The sharp peaks of TP-POP remained unchanged in the XRD pattern of CuI-TP-POP catalyst, demonstrating that the structure of the polymer not changed after complexation [70]. The observed new peaks reveal the incorporation of CuI with TP-POP and formation of a new material. The observed peaks at 2θ=26.1, 30.6, 42.0, 44.2, 49.5, 64.4, 67.2 and 77.0 refer to CuI [74]. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the TP-POP and CuI-TP-POP are shown in Fig. 6 . The TGA of TP-POP shows a main weight loss at 350–400°C which is related to decomposition of the compound structure. The TGA analysis of TP-POP indicates the high thermal stability of this material. The TGA analysis of CuI-TP-POP shows three main loses. The first one accounts for the adsorbed water in the structure of the material. The second one occurred at 300–400°C which is related to the decomposition of TP-POP support. The third decrease in the weight percentage of the material at 400–480°C is related to decomposition of the CuI complex with TP-POP substrate. The TGA analysis of the TP-POP and CuI-TP-POP clearly demonstrate the high thermal stability of the materials for catalysis application at high temperature and also strong binding between the metal and organic substrate. 2.2 Catalytic application of CuI-TP-POP catalyst in Ullmann-type reaction The synthetic usefulness of the CuI-TP-POP was evaluated in the O-arylation reaction between phenols and aryl halides which is known as Ullmann reaction [75]. The reaction between p-cresol and bromobenzene was selected as the model reaction in order to find the optimum conditions for O-arylation process using CuI-TP-POP catalyst. The obtained results are shown in Table 1 . In the presence of CuI-TP-POP catalyst in DMSO solvent and using NaOtBu as base, 75% of the coupling product was obtained (Table 1, entry 1). By change of the base to K2CO3, Cs2CO3, and K3PO4 the reaction yield was slightly improved to 78% yield using K3PO4 (Table 1, entries 2–4). Then, the type of reaction media was changed to H2O, EG, PEG-200, dioxane, and DMF and maximum yield of the product was obtained in PEG-200 (Table 1, entries 5–9). Thus, PEG-200 was selected as the reaction media and K3PO4 as base for this reaction. The catalyst loading and reaction temperature were also optimized and 4 mol% of CuI-TP-POP and 100°C were selected as optimum (Table 1, entries 10–14). The optimized conditions for coupling of phenols and aryl bromides are shown in the entry 10 of Table 1. By use of aryl chloride instead of aryl bromide coupling product was observed in low yield under the optimized conditions after 24h. Iodobenzene was coupled with p-cresol under the optimized conditions and 90% of diaryl ether product was obtained after 6h. These results demonstrate that the introduce CuI-TP-POP catalyst system is efficient for O-arylation of aryl halides under mild and environmentally being conditions. After establishing the optimal conditions (Table 1), the substrate scope of this new O-arylation methodology we examined (Scheme 2 ). As shown in Scheme 2, different phenolic compounds and aryl halides were coupled under our optimized conditions to produce a range of diaryl ethers in good to excellent yields (Scheme 2). A variety of functional groups (Me, OMe, NO2, halogen, thio, CHO, CN) on the aryl rings of both the phenolic compounds and the aryl halides tolerated the reaction conditions. Reactions of the substrates with electron withdrawing or donating groups on aryl rings of both coupling partners perform smoothly. The reaction showed good selectivity between halogens substituents (Cl & Br; Br & I) as leaving groups (3f, 3h, 3m). A good yield of product was obtained using the reaction of 2-naphthol and bromobenzene and iodobenzene (3i). A sterically hindered phenol was used and the coupling product was synthesized in good yield (3j). Also, 2-hydroxy-4-nitrobenzaldehyde was coupled with iodobenzene efficiently (3k). 4-Flourophenol was efficiently coupled with 2-bromopyridine and the corresponding product was generated in 80% isolated yield (3l). Reaction of Sesamol with aryl halides resulted to the synthesis of new diaryl ethers containing this biological active fragments (3m–o) [76]. Reaction of 4-(benzylthio)phenol with some aryl halides resulted in the synthesis of some new diaryl ethers containing both ether and thioether linkages (3p–r). Low yields of the products for aryl chlorides were observed even at longer reaction times, demonstrating that these coupling partners have less activity under our optimized reaction conditions (3a, 3b, 3g, 3i, and 3n). Next, we investigated the catalyst reusability of CuI-TP-POP in O-arylation reaction under our optimized conditions. The recycled catalyst was reused five times without significant decrease in its catalytic activity (Fig. 7 ). In order to have more information about the structure of the catalyst after using in the reaction, we analyzed the Cu content of the catalyst using ICP after 5 times of reusability and the results showed that only 0.5% of Cu was lost. These results are in good agreement with catalyst activity of the CuI-TP-POP catalyst after each recovery. A hot filtration test was also accomplished in order to investigate the leaching of Cu from the TPC substrate. In this way, after the first run, the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture in hot form and the reaction vessel was charged with the starting material again. The obtained results demonstrated that less than 3% of the product was produced. These results confirm that the CuI-TP-POP system act as catalyst and no leached Cu, representing that CuI-TP-POP is heterogeneous in practice. A reaction mechanism for O-arylation of phenols by aryl halides in the presence of CuI-TP-POP catalyst is proposed according to the literature (Scheme 3 ) [75]. A part of TP-POP is considered in order to show the catalytic activity of the present catalytic sites in the structure of polymer. The P,N-ligation sites can coordinate with CuI metal and generate Cu(I) centers in the structure of polymer which is the catalytic site of heterogeneous catalyst. In these catalytic sites with centers of Cu(I), oxidative addition of aryl halides resulted in the production of intermediate A. This intermediate can react with the deprotonated phenolic compounds to produce intermediate B. Reductive elimination of the intermediate B leds to the formation of biaryl ether product and regeneration of the catalyst to undergo in the next cycle. 3 Conclusion In conclusion we have introduced an efficient synthetic methodology for synthesis of biaryl ethers using phenolic compounds and aryl halides. A heterogeneous copper catalyst system was developed using immobilization of CuI on a triazine-phosphite porous organic polymer. The synthetic route for the preparation of CuI-TP-POP catalyst is simple and starting materials are cheap and available. The CuI-TP-POP catalyst shows high catalytic activity in the synthesis of biaryl ethers using the reaction of phenolic compounds and aryl halides. A range of biaryl ethers were synthesized using CuI-TP-POP under optimized conditions. The CuI-TP-POP catalyst was reusable at least for 5 times without considerable decreasing in its catalytic activity. Moreover, the CuI-TP-POP catalyst provides great promise towards further useful applications in other copper-catalyzed organic transformations in the future. 4 Experimental section 4.1 General Chemicals and all reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. 1H NMR (250MHz) and 13C NMR (62.5MHz) spectra were recorded on a Brucker Avance DPX-250 spectrometer in deuterated chloroform (CDCl3) and deuterated dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO-d 6) solutions with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard. Chemical shifts were reported in ppm (δ), and coupling constants in Hz (J). X-ray diffraction (XRD, D8, Advance, Bruker, axs) and Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy with a Shimadzu FTIR-8300 spectrophotometer, was employed for characterization of the catalysts and products. Melting points were determined in open capillary tubes using a Barnstead electro-thermal 9100 BZ circulating oil melting point apparatus. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was obtained using a TEM apparatus (CM-10-Philips, 100kV) for characterization of the catalyst. The scanning electron micrography (SEM) images for the catalyst were obtained by SEM instrumentation (SEM, XL-30 FEG SEM, Philips, at 20kV). The amount of Cu supported on TP-POP was measured using an ICP analyzer (Varian, Vista-pro) and atomic absorption spectroscopy. The reaction monitoring was carried out on silica gel analytical sheets and column chromatography was carried out on column of silica gel. Thin layer chromatography was carried out on silica gel 254 analytical sheets obtained from Fluka. 4.2 Synthesis of triazine-phosphite compound (TP-POP) Into a canonical flask 20.0mmol of cyanuric acid (which previously highly powdered) is added to a 60mmol of (n-Pr)3N and permit it to stir for 1h at 60–80°C. Then, the reaction mixture was cooled down to room temperature. Afterward, 20.0mmol of PCl3 is added to the reaction mixture drop wise under argon gas. Then the reaction temperature increased to 80°C and is stirred for 12h under argon gas. The obtained crude yellow product was washed with water (2×25mL). After drying it was washed with ethyl acetate (2×20mL) in order to remove the un-reacted organic starting materials. To obtain a high uniform powder it was stirred in a mixture of EtOAc and n-hexane (1:1) for 1h at room temperature. After drying in oven the TP-POP was obtained as a yellow powder. 4.3 Synthesis of CuI-TP-POP Into a canonical flask CuI (0.190g, 1.0mmol) is added to a solution of the TP-POP substrate (1.0g) in DMF (10mL) and permit it to stir for 12h at 50°C. After the completion of complex formation, a color change was observed. The resulting product was filtered, washed with ethanol, and dried at 70°C. 4.4 General procedure for synthesis of biaryl ethers using CuI-TP-POP catalyst Aryl halide (1.0mmol), ArOH (1.1mmol), CuI-TP-POP (4mol%), K3PO4 (1.5mmol), and PEG-200 (2.0mL) was placed in a 25mL flask equipped with a magnetic stirring bar and heated at 100°C under nitrogen gas. The reaction was then monitored by TLC until the consumption of aryl halide was detected. After completion of the reaction 5mL of water and 5mL of EtOAc were added to the reaction mixture. The organic solution was extracted and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. After removing of organic solvent the crude product was obtained. For further purification the chromatography technique was used. coredata.dc:description: Immobilized copper iodide on a triazine-phosphite porous organic polymer (CuI-TP-POP) was introduced as a novel heterogeneous catalyst, to be used in CO band formation reaction. The CuI-TP-POP catalyst was synthesized by complexation of CuI with a triazine-phosphite porous organic polymer (TP-POP), incorporating P,N-ligation sites. The TP-POP substrate is a porous material in sheet morphology with cavities in the range of nanometer scale incorporating P and N atoms. These nano-cavities create appropriate ligation sites on the surface of TP-POP with chelation character to coordinate with CuI, leading to the formation of a heterogeneous copper (I) catalyst. The CuI-TP-POP was found to be an efficient heterogeneous catalyst in CO bond formation reaction between phenolic compounds and aryl halides toward synthesis of diaryl ethers in high isolated yields. This catalyst system was reusable at least for five times without significant decreasing in its catalytic activity.
coredata.dc:title: Immobilized copper iodide on a porous organic polymer bearing P,N-ligation sites: A highly efficient heterogeneous catalyst for CO bond formation reaction
